Although many of the extracellular ligands and nuclear transcription factors responsible for embryonic cartilage differentiation have been documented, comparatively little is known about the cytoplasmic protein kinase cascades that relay cell surface signals to the internal gene regulators. Protein kinase A activity may positively regulate chondrogenesis by promoting cartilage nodule formation (18Yoon Y.M. Oh C.D. Kang S.S. Chun J.S. J. Bone Miner. Res. 2000; 15: 2197-2205Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar), and protein kinase C expression is up-regulated during in vitro chondrogenesis (19Choi B. Chun J.S. Lee Y.S. Sonn J.K. Kang S.S. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1995; 216: 1034-1040Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar). In addition, the extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK) and p38 mitogen-activated protein kinases have been recently implicated as important intracellular mediators of embryonic chondrocyte differentiation. bone morphogenetic protein extracellular signal-regulated kinase mitogen-activated protein kinase/extracellular signal-regulated kinase kinase constitutively active human MEK1 catalytically inactive human MEK1 glycosaminoglycan(s) fetal bovine serum glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase cytomegalovirus. The ERK pathway, also known as the MEK-ERK kinase cascade, is one of the preeminent cytoplasmic signal transduction pathways governing the proliferation, survival, and differentiation of eukaryotic cells (21Chang F. Steelman L.S. Shelton J.G. Lee J.T. Navolanic P.M. Blalock W.L. Franklin R. McCubrey J.A. Int. J. Oncol. 2003; 22: 469-480PubMed Google Scholar, 22Johnson G.L. Lapadat R. Science. 2002; 298: 1911-1912Crossref PubMed Scopus (3542) Google Scholar). The MEK-ERK cascade consists of three serially phosphorylating protein kinases (Raf, MEK, and ERK) that typically function downstream of cell surface receptors for growth factors and mitogens. These G-protein-coupled receptors recruit, via GDP/GTP exchange factors and adapter proteins, the small guanosine triphosphatase (GTPase), Ras. Ras activates the Raf family of serine threonine kinases (A-Raf, B-Raf, or c-Raf1). The Raf kinases, in turn, activate MEK1 and MEK2. MEK1 and -2 activate ERK1 and ERK2, their only known downstream substrates, by dual phosphorylation at their TEY motif (23Hilger R.A. Scheulen M.E. Strumberg D. Onkologie. 2002; 25: 511-518Crossref PubMed Scopus (245) Google Scholar). ERK phosphorylation results in dissociation from its cytoplasmic anchor MEK, nuclear translocation, and subsequent phosphorylation of various transcription factors, including Elk-1, Rsk, ERF, c-Myc, and Cbfa1 (24Adachi M. Fukuda M. Nishida E. EMBO J. 1999; 18: 5347-5358Crossref PubMed Scopus (242) Google Scholar, 25Weinstein-Oppenheimer C.R. Blalock W.L. Steelman L.S. Chang F. McCubrey J.A. Pharmacol. Ther. 2000; 88: 229-279Crossref PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar, 26Bushweller J.H. Semin. Cell Dev. Biol. 2000; 11: 377-382Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar). Recently, the MEK-ERK kinase cascade has been implicated in the process of embryonic cartilage differentiation; however, its precise role remains controversial. Murakami et al. (7Murakami S. Kan M. McKeehan W.L. de Crombrugghe B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 1113-1118Crossref PubMed Scopus (313) Google Scholar) interpreted the MEK-ERK cascade as a positive regulator of chondrogenesis, since, in cultured costal chondrocytes, the pharmacological MEK inhibitor U0126 diminished fibroblast growth factor 2-induced increases in Sox9 protein levels. In addition, transfection of a constitutively active MEK1 mutant up-regulated activity of a Sox9-dependent collagen II enhancer in both costal chondrocytes and C3H10T1/2 cells, a pluripotent mesenchymal progenitor cell line (7Murakami S. Kan M. McKeehan W.L. de Crombrugghe B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 1113-1118Crossref PubMed Scopus (313) Google Scholar). In contrast, other studies describe the MEK-ERK kinase cascade as a negative modulator of cartilage differentiation. Endogenous ERK activity was observed to decrease during spontaneous chondrogenesis in micromass cultures of embryonic chick limb mesenchyme cells (27Chang S.H. Oh C.D. Yang M.S. Kang S.S. Lee Y.S. Sonn J.K. Chun J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 19213-19219Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (87) Google Scholar), and epidermal growth factor-induced inhibition of in vitro chondrogenesis coincided with increased ERK1 phosphorylation (8Yoon Y.M. Oh C.D. Kim D.Y. Lee Y.S. Park J.W. Huh T.L. Kang S.S. Chun J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 12353-12359Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar). Furthermore, the MEK inhibitor PD98059 was reported to enhance cartilage matrix formation in limb mesenchyme micromass cultures as evidenced by collagen II immunostaining and Alcian blue histochemistry (27Chang S.H. Oh C.D. Yang M.S. Kang S.S. Lee Y.S. Sonn J.K. Chun J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 19213-19219Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (87) Google Scholar, 28Oh C.D. Chang S.H. Yoon Y.M. Lee S.J. Lee Y.S. Kang S.S. Chun J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 5613-5619Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (200) Google Scholar). More recently, Seghatoleslami et al. (29Seghatoleslami M.R. Roman-Blas J.A. Rainville A.M. Modaressi R. Danielson K.G. Tuan R.S. J. Cell. Biochem. 2003; 88: 1129-1144Crossref PubMed Scopus (29) Google Scholar) reported that PD98059 elevates type II collagen and sox9 gene transcript levels in C3H10T1/2 cells, as determined by semiquantitative reverse transcriptase-PCR analysis. The present study was performed to better define the role of the MEK-ERK kinase cascade in chondrogenic differentiation of embryonic limb mesenchyme cells. To more thoroughly examine the effects of MEK inhibition on chondrogenesis, micromass cultures of prechondrogenic limb mesenchyme were treated with two different pharmacological MEK inhibitors, U0126 and PD98059. The effects of the two MEK inhibitors on expression of the cartilage-specific marker genes, type II collagen, aggrecan, and sox9, were compared utilizing RNA dot blot analysis. Effects on cartilage matrix proteoglycan synthesis and secretion were examined by measurement of radioactive 35SO4 uptake into sulfated glycosaminoglycans (GAG) and by histochemical staining. Immunocytochemical staining was used to examine the effects of the pharmacological MEK inhibitors on type II collagen production. To directly analyze the effects of increased MEK activity on in vitro chondrogenesis, micromass cultures of prechondrogenic limb mesenchyme cells were transfected with a constitutively active MEK expression plasmid. Our results support the hypothesis that the MEK-ERK kinase cascade functions as an inhibitory modulator of chondrocyte differentiation in embryonic limb mesenchyme cells. However, some differences in the responses of the prechondrogenic cells to U0126 and PD98059 treatments suggest that the two putative MEK inhibitors do not have completely equivalent target specificities. Preparation of Micromass Cultures—High density micromass cultures of embryonic chick limb mesenchyme were established as previously described (13Kulyk W.M. Franklin J.L. Hoffman L.M. Exp. Cell Res. 2000; 255: 327-332Crossref PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar, 30Kulyk W.M. Dev. Biol. 1991; 146: 38-48Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). Briefly, mesenchyme tissue was isolated from whole wing buds of stage 23/24 (31Hamburger V. Hamilton H.L. J. Morphol. 1951; 88: 49-92Crossref PubMed Scopus (10048) Google Scholar) chick embryos or from the distal tips of stage 24/25 chick embryo wing buds (32Gay S.W. Kosher R.A. J. Exp. Zool. 1984; 232: 317-326Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar). After 25 min in 0.25% trypsin, the mesenchyme was dissociated into a single cell suspension at a density of 1–2 × 107 cells/ml, and 10-μl drops of cell suspension were spotted onto tissue culture dishes. Unless otherwise stated, a single 10-μl drop of cell suspension was spotted onto each 15-mm diameter well of either 4-well or 24-well NUNC tissue culture dishes. After spotting, the dishes were preincubated for 90 min at 37 °C to permit cell attachment. The cultures were then fed with F-12/10% FBS medium (Ham's F-12 medium containing 10% fetal bovine serum, 2 mm glutamine, and antibiotics) and incubated at 37 °C in a 5% CO2 plus 95% air atmosphere for up to 3 days without further medium change. Following incubation, cultures were processed for Alcian blue staining, type II collagen immunostaining, Western blotting, RNA dot blot analysis, or measurement of sulfated GAG synthesis. Pharmacological MEK inhibitors—F-12/10% FBS culture medium was supplemented with U0126 or PD98059 (Calbiochem) at 20 μm final concentrations. Unless otherwise stated, the MEK inhibitors were added to the culture medium at the time of initial feeding as concentrated stock solutions dissolved in Me2SO. Control cultures were supplemented with Me2SO vehicle alone (0.1% final concentration). Histochemistry and Immunostaining—To demonstrate sulfated cartilage matrix proteoglycan accumulation, representative cultures were collected after 3 days of incubation and stained with 0.5% Alcian blue 8GX, pH 1.0, as described (33Hassell J.R. Horigan E.A. Teratog. Carcinog. Mutagen. 1982; 2: 325-331Crossref PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar). Alcian blue dye bound to matrix proteoglycans was extracted with 4 m guanidine hydrochloride and quantified by measuring absorbance at 600 nm (27Chang S.H. Oh C.D. Yang M.S. Kang S.S. Lee Y.S. Sonn J.K. Chun J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 19213-19219Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (87) Google Scholar). To demonstrate type II collagen deposition, cultures were fixed for 30 min in 95% ethanol containing 2% acetic acid, incubated overnight in 70% ethanol, and then rehydrated and postfixed for 1 h in 4% paraformaldehyde. Cultures were subsequently incubated for 1 h with a 1:50 dilution of hybridoma supernatant containing chicken collagen II monoclonal antibody II-II6B3 (Developmental Studies Hybridoma Bank, University of Iowa), washed, and incubated for 1 h with alkaline phosphatase-conjugated goat anti-mouse IgG (antibody A-1293 at 1:250 dilution; Sigma). Color development was performed using nitro blue tetrazolium chloride (0.34 mg/ml) and 5-bromo-4-chloro-3-indolylphosphate (0.175 mg/ml) dissolved in 100 mm Tris-HCl, pH 9.5, 50 mm MgCl2, 100 mm NaCl, 0.1% Triton X-100, 0.05% levamisole. Western Blot Analysis—For Western blot analysis, cultures were established on 35-mm NUNC tissue culture dishes (eight 10-μl micromass spot cultures per dish). Denaturing polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and protein transfer to nitrocellulose were performed using the Bio-Rad Protean II Minigel apparatus according to a standard protocol. Micromass cultures from a single plate were homogenized in lysis buffer consisting of 50 mm Tris, pH 7.4, 150 mm NaCl, 1% Nonidet P-40, 0.1% SDS, supplemented with protease and phosphatase inhibitors (Sigma). Proteins were separated on 10% polyacrylamide containing 0.1% SDS. ERK was detected using polyclonal antibody sc-94 against total ERK1/2 (Santa Cruz Biotechnology) and monoclonal antibody 9101S against dual phosphorylated ERK1/2 (Cell Signaling Technology). Primary antibodies were detected using appropriate horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibodies (Bio-Rad) and the Western blot Chemiluminescence Reagent Plus system (PerkinElmer Life Sciences) as per the manufacturer's instructions. RNA Dot Blot Analysis—For RNA analysis, cultures were established on 35-mm NUNC tissue culture dishes (usually 4–8 10-μl micromass spot cultures/dish). Total RNA was isolated from the micromass cultures on each plate using Trizol reagent (Invitrogen) as previously described (34Hoffman L.M. Kulyk W.M. Int. J. Dev. Biol. 1999; 43: 167-174PubMed Google Scholar). The relative RNA contents of each sample were determined by RiboGreen (Molecular Probes, Inc., Eugene, OR) fluorescence assay according to the manufacturer's protocol. Equal aliquots of total RNA were spotted onto nitrocellulose (MSI Nitroplus) using a 96-well BioDot apparatus (Bio-Rad). Membranes were then hybridized with single-stranded cDNA probes specific for chicken sox9, aggrecan, and type II collagen (col2α1) mRNAs or with an oligonucleotide probe for the chicken glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH) gene transcript. All cDNA probes were labeled to high specific activity with [32P]dCTP following the method of Konat (35Konat G.W. Scanning Microsc. Suppl. 1996; 10: 57-60PubMed Google Scholar); the GAPDH oligonucleotide was 5′-end-labeled with 32P using T4 polynucleotide kinase. Hybridization and washes were performed at high stringency as previously described (13Kulyk W.M. Franklin J.L. Hoffman L.M. Exp. Cell Res. 2000; 255: 327-332Crossref PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar, 36Kosher R.A. Gay S.W. Kamanitz J.R. Kulyk W.M. Rodgers B.J. Sai S. Tanaka T. Tanzer M.L. Dev. Biol. 1986; 118: 112-117Crossref PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar, 37Kosher R.A. Kulyk W.M. Gay S.W. J. Cell Biol. 1986; 102: 1151-1156Crossref PubMed Scopus (200) Google Scholar). The specificities of all probes under the hybridization condition employed were established in earlier studies (13Kulyk W.M. Franklin J.L. Hoffman L.M. Exp. Cell Res. 2000; 255: 327-332Crossref PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar, 36Kosher R.A. Gay S.W. Kamanitz J.R. Kulyk W.M. Rodgers B.J. Sai S. Tanaka T. Tanzer M.L. Dev. Cell Biol. 1986; 102: 1151-1156Crossref PubMed Scopus (200) Google Scholar) and confirmed by Northern blot analysis. The sox9 and GAPDH probes are described by Kulyk et al. (13Kulyk W.M. Franklin J.L. Hoffman L.M. Exp. Cell Res. 2000; 255: 327-332Crossref PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar). The cDNA probes for chicken col2α1 and aggrecan were pCAR2 (38Vuorio E. Sandell L. Kravis D. Sheffield V.C. Vuorio T. Dorfman A. Upholt W.B. Nucleic Acids Res. 1982; 10: 1175-1192Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar) and ST-1 (39Sai S. Tanaka T. Kosher R.A. Tanzer M.L. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1986; 83: 5081-5085Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar). Hybridization signals for all probes were quantified by densitometric measurements on properly exposed autoradiographs using a Tecan SLT Spectra II spectrophotometric plate reader. To correct for slight variations in sample loading, hybridization signals for cartilage-specific mRNAs were normalized against signals for the constitutively expressed GAPDH transcript. Analysis of sulfated GAG Accumulation—F-12/10% FBS culture medium was supplemented with 5 μCi/ml [35S]H2SO4 (carrier-free; PerkinElmer Life Sciences), and the cells were continuously labeled over a 3-day incubation period. Sulfated GAG was isolated from both the cell layer and the medium fractions of the cultures by precipitation with cetylpyridinium chloride as previously described (30Kulyk W.M. Dev. Biol. 1991; 146: 38-48Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar, 40Kosher R.A. Dev. Biol. 1976; 53: 265-276Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar). GAG-incorporated label was quantified by liquid scintillation counting and normalized against the DNA content of each culture as determined by the Hoechst 33258 fluorescence assay (41Labarca C. Paigen K. Anal. Biochem. 1980; 102: 344-352Crossref PubMed Scopus (4553) Google Scholar). Transfection of Micromass Cultures—Prechondrogenic mesenchyme cells isolated from whole stage 23/24 wing buds or the distal tips of stage 24/25 chick embryo limb buds were suspended at a density of 2 × 107 cells/ml in F-12/5% FBS medium. The cells were transiently transfected with plasmid DNA using Lipofectin reagent (Invitrogen) following the manufacturer's protocol. Briefly, 0.75 μg of MEK expression vector, 0.75 μg of collagen II enhancer-firefly luciferase reporter plasmid, and 0.0375 μg of CMV-Renilla luciferase construct were combined in 100 μl of Opti-MEM medium (Invitrogen) and then added to an equal volume of Lipofectin/Opti-MEM (6:100) mixture. For transfection purposes, 100 μl of mesenchymal suspension (2 × 106 cells) was combined 2:1 (v/v) with the Lipofectin-DNA complex. Following a 5-min incubation at room temperature, 15-μl spots of cell suspension (2 × 105 cells/spot) were plated onto 4-well NUNC culture dishes (1 spot/well). After 60 min at 37 °C in a 5% CO2 plus 95% air incubator, the cultures were flooded with F-12/5% FBS medium lacking antibiotics. Six hours later, the culture medium was replaced with F-12/5% FBS containing antibiotics. The cultures were incubated for a total of 2 days and then collected for determination of firefly luciferase and Renilla luciferase activities using the Dual Luciferase Reporter Assay System (Promega) following the manufacturer's protocol. Luciferase measurements were performed on cells from each individual culture well, with a minimum of eight replicates per treatment group. Measurements were performed on a Turner Designs TD20/20 luminometer. To correct for variations in transfection efficiency, activities of the collagen II enhancer-firefly luciferase reporter gene were normalized against activity of the co-transfected CMV-Renilla luciferase construct. MEK expression vectors under the control of the CMV promoter were generously provided by Natalie Ahn (University of Colorado, Boulder, CO). The plasmid encoding constitutively active human MEK1 (CA-MEK1) was construct hMKK1-N3/S218E/S222D (42Mansour S.J. Candia J.M. Gloor K.K. Ahn N.G. Cell Growth Differ. 1996; 7: 243-250PubMed Google Scholar). The catalytically inactive MEK1 vector (CI-MEK1) was plasmid hMKK1-K97M (43Mansour S.J. Candia J.M. Matsuura J.E. Manning M.C. Ahn N.G. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 15529-15536Crossref PubMed Scopus (120) Google Scholar). The corresponding empty vector was pCEP4L (42Mansour S.J. Candia J.M. Gloor K.K. Ahn N.G. Cell Growth Differ. 1996; 7: 243-250PubMed Google Scholar). The collagen II enhancer-firefly luciferase reporter was provided by T. Michael Underhill (University of Western Ontario) and contained four repeats of the 48-bp Sox9-responsive enhancer sequence of the mouse col2α1 gene (44Weston A.D. Chandraratna R.A. Torchia J. Underhill T.M. J. Cell Biol. 2002; 158: 39-51Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar) cloned in vector pGL3. The CMV-Renilla luciferase plasmid (pRL-CMV) was purchased from Promega. To test the effects of U0126 and PD98059 on collagen II enhancer activity, cells were transfected with the collagen II enhancer-firefly luciferase reporter plasmid alone. The MEK inhibitors were added to the cultures at the time of antibiotic addition (7 h after initial plating; see above). Luciferase activity was normalized against total cellular DNA as determined by a fluorescence assay (41Labarca C. Paigen K. Anal. Biochem. 1980; 102: 344-352Crossref PubMed Scopus (4553) Google Scholar). Statistical Analysis—Quantitative data pertaining to Alcian blue staining, mRNA expression, sulfated GAG accumulation, and luciferase activity were analyzed by one-way analysis of variance with either Dunnett or Tukey multiple comparison post-tests (GraphPad Prism 4 software). Effects of the MEK Inhibitors, U0126 and PD98059, on Alcian Blue-stainable Matrix Proteoglycan Accumulation—We first examined the effects of the two putative MEK inhibitors, U0126 and PD98059, on the accumulation of histochemically identifiable cartilage matrix proteoglycans. Micromass cultures prepared from whole stage 23/24 chick embryo wing buds or from the distal mesenchyme of stage 24/25 wing buds were stained with Alcian blue dye following 3 days of incubation in medium supplemented with 20 μm U0126, 20 μm PD98059, or 0.1% Me2SO vehicle alone (controls). Cultures of stage 23/24 whole limb mesenchyme (Fig. 1, upper row) form numerous discrete Alcian blue-positive cartilage nodules separated by areas of unstained tissue, due to the presence of both chondrogenic and myogenic progenitor cells. In these whole limb mesenchyme cultures, PD98059 treatment stimulated a visible increase in Alcian blue-positive matrix accumulation relative to untreated control cultures (Fig. 1), while U0126 treatment caused no discernible increase. Quantitation of the histochemical staining confirmed that PD98059 increased Alcian blue-positive matrix proteoglycan deposition ∼1.9-fold over untreated control cultures (p < 0.001; n = 4), whereas U0126 treatment had no significant effect on Alcian blue-stainable cartilage matrix production (p > 0.05; n = 4). Micromass cultures of stage 24/25 distal limb mesenchyme (Fig. 1, lower row) contain a more uniform population of prechondrogenic cells that is uncontaminated by myoblast precursors. As such, their pa

c-Jun NH2-terminal kinases (JNKs) potentiate transcriptional activity of c-Jun by phosphorylating serines 63 and 73. Moreover, JNK and c-Jun can modulate apoptosis. However, an involvement of nitric oxide (NO)-induced phosphorylation of c-Jun on Ser-63 and Ser-73 in apoptosis has not been explored. We report that in SH-Sy5y neuroblastoma cells, NO induced apoptosis following JNK activation and phosphorylation of c-Jun almost exclusively on Ser-63. Importantly, NO-induced apoptosis and caspase-3 activity were inhibited in cells stably transformed with dominant-negative c-Jun in which Ser-63 is mutated to alanine (S63A), but not in cells transformed with dominant-negative c-Jun (S73A). Ser-63 of c-Jun (but not Ser-73) was required for NO-induced, c-Jun-dependent transcriptional activity. NO-induced apoptosis, Ser-63 phosphorylation of c-Jun, and caspase-3 activity were all inhibited in SH-Sy5y cells transformed with dominant-negative jnk. A caspase-3 inhibitor prevented apoptosis but not c-Jun phosphorylation. In a different neuroblastoma cell line, NO-induced Ser-63 phosphorylation of c-Jun and apoptosis were blocked by a specific JNK inhibitor. We conclude that NO-inducible apoptosis is mediated by JNK-dependent Ser-63 phosphorylation of c-Jun upstream of caspase-3 activation in neuroblastoma cells. c-Jun NH2-terminal kinases (JNKs) potentiate transcriptional activity of c-Jun by phosphorylating serines 63 and 73. We conclude that NO-inducible apoptosis is mediated by JNK-dependent Ser-63 phosphorylation of c-Jun upstream of caspase-3 activation in neuroblastoma cells. Thus, much evidence suggests that c-Jun phosphorylation is often but not always proapoptotic, particularly in neuronal cells.We reported recently that in SH-Sy5y cells, the constitutive activity of c-Jun/AP-1 in the absence of detectable AP-1 DNA binding is required for the expression of the neural cell adhesion molecule NCAM-140 (31Feng Z. Li L. Ng P.Y. Porter A.G. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2002; 22: 5357-5366Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar). This basal c-Jun/AP-1-dependent synthesis of NCAM-140 counteracts NO-induced apoptosis. Here, we investigated whether NO induces c-Jun phosphorylation and regulates apoptosis through the JNK-c-Jun pathway, as do other cellular stressors. Notably, we found that JNK-dependent phosphorylation of c-Jun on Ser-63 promotes NO-induced apoptosis of neuroblastoma cells. A speculative model is proposed which can account for the pro- and antiapoptotic action of c-Jun/AP-1 within a single neuroblastoma cell.EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURESMaterials and Plasmid Constructions—The human neuroblastoma cell lines SH-Sy5y and SHEP were obtained from Eva Feldman (University of Michigan, Ann Arbor) and from Evelyne Goillot (Laboratoire d'Immunologie, Centre Leon Berard, Lyon, France), respectively. The polyclonal antibodies against phospho-c-Jun, phospho-JNK, c-Jun, and JNK were from Cell Signaling Technology. The antibody against actin was from Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc.
