Single phagosomes were bleached for 1 s, and fluorescence recovery was subsequently measured. The recovery kinetics for untreated cells and for cells treated with the actin-modifying compounds cytochalasin B and latrunculin A were determined. Shown are representative curves for each condition. Relative fluorescence at a given time point is defined as the ratio of fluorescence of the bleached spot over the whole cell at a given time point divided by the ratio of fluorescence of the bleached spot over the whole cell at t = 0.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) The NADPH oxidase of phagocytic leukocytes consists of the membrane-bound flavocytochrome b558 and three essential cytosolic components, p47phox, p67phox, and Rac2. In this report, the localization of p67phox and Rac2 during NADPH oxidase activation was studied by means of GFP fusions of these proteins. The p67GFP fusion protein was first tested for its ability to support superoxide production in K562 cells expressing all essential NADPH oxidase components but lacking p67phox expression. Expression of the fusion protein was seen to restore the superoxide-producing capacity of the K562 cells. Initially, the same approach was taken for p47phox, but the p47GFP fusion protein was not able to restore superoxide production in K562 cells lacking p47phox (data not shown); therefore, this construct was not used in this study. The GFP-Rac2 could not be tested in a similar manner, but the GFP-Rac2 fusion protein did not have deleterious effects on superoxide production by K562 cells. Expressed in a granulocytic cell line, p67GFP and GFP-Rac2 show the same intracellular localization as the endogenous proteins during STZ phagocytosis. Additionally, their localization was disturbed in later stages of phagocytosis in cells that lack gp91phox, which is consistent with experiments performed previously with these cell lines as well as with granulocytes from CGD patients (18Allen L.A. DeLeo F.R. Gallois A. Toyoshima S. Suzuki K. Nauseef W.M. Blood. 1999; 93: 3521-3530Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 30Grogan A. Reeves E. Keep N. Wientjes F. Totty N.F. Burlingame A.L. Hsuan J.J. Segal A.W. J. Cell Sci. 1997; 110: 3071-3081Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). During phagosome formation, the translocation of the cytoplasmic NADPH oxidase components and their subsequent interaction with flavocytochrome b558 may result in the formation of a stable complex of these proteins. Alternatively, the cytoplasmic components p47phox, p67phox, and Rac2 may only transiently associate with flavocytochrome b558. Since the translocation of the cytosolic NADPH oxidase components is rapidly terminated in cells that lack flavocytochrome b558, it is generally believed that flavocytochrome b558 and the cytosolic proteins form a stable complex, resulting in the containment of the cytosolic proteins at the phagosomal membrane. To determine the turnover of p67GFP and GFP-Rac2 on the phagosome, FRAP experiments were performed. The fluorescence recovery of both proteins was extremely rapid, indicating that there is continuous exchange of soluble p67GFP and GFP-Rac2 for flavocytochrome b558-bound p67GFP and GFP-Rac2, even after complete internalization of zymosan particles. This is in accordance with a previous study in which evidence was obtained, suggesting that a limited amount of cytosolic components can activate an excess of flavocytochrome b558, which also argues against the formation of a stoichiometric complex between the cytosolic factors and flavocytochrome b558 (31Cross A.R. Erickson R.W. Curnutte J.T. Biochem. J. 1999; 341: 251-255Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Furthermore, Akard et al. (32Akard L.P. English D. Gabig T.G. Blood. 1988; 72: 322-327Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) have provided evidence that sustained superoxide production is a result of continuous replenishment of a pool of active NADPH oxidase, which is also in line with the data obtained in this study. The presence of flavocytochrome b558 in the membrane is crucial for the observed continuous translocation of the cytosolic proteins, as illustrated by the loss of p67GFP and GFP-Rac2 from the phagosomes of PLB-985 X-CGD cells. This is in sharp contrast to the translocation of the cytosolic proteins to nascent phagosomes, which clearly does not depend on the presence of flavocytochrome b558, since p67GFP and GFP-Rac2 localize correctly during this stage of phagocytosis in PLB-985 X-CGD cells. Furthermore, the involvement of the actin cytoskeleton in the translocation of p67phox and Rac2 during phagocytosis was investigated by the use of an actin-modifying agent. The effect of cytochalasin B, a potent actin depolymerizing agent, on the translocation behavior of p67GFP and GFP-Rac2 was tested. Pretreatment of PLB-985 cells with this compound prevented an increase in the amount of p67GFP and GFP-Rac2 at the binding site of STZ, identifying the importance of the actin cytoskeleton in the initiation of the translocation of p67GFP and GFP-Rac2. It remains unclear why disruption of the actin cytoskeleton disturbs the primary translocation of the cytosolic factors. Rac2, p40phox, and p47phox have been shown to be able to interact with the membrane through their prenylated C terminus or PX domains, respectively (14Stahelin R.V. Burian A. Bruzik K.S. Murray D. Cho W. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; Google Scholar, 33Tao W. Filippi M.D. Bailey J.R. Atkinson S.J. Connors B. Evan A. Williams D.A. Blood. 2002; 100: 1679-1688Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 34Ando S. Kaibuchi K. Sasaki T. Hiraoka K. Nishiyama T. Mizuno T. Asada M. Nunoi H. Matsuda I. Matsuura Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 25709-25713Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In cytochalasin B-treated cells, the interaction of the PX domains of p40phox and p47phox with the phosphoinositides formed in the membrane after binding of STZ particles to cell surface receptors was anticipated to still occur, as well as the interaction of Rac2 with the membrane. However, the translocation of p67GFP and GFP-Rac2 is absent in cytochalasin B-treated cells upon binding of zymosan particles, which identifies the association of these proteins with the actin cytoskeleton as a step preceding the interaction of these proteins with the membrane and flavocytochrome b558. In contrast, cytochalasin B had no effect on the localization and continuous exchange of p67GFP and GFP-Rac2 on the phagosomal membrane when phagocytosis had already been initiated. According to our data, the translocation of cytosolic NADPH oxidase components is independent of the actin cytoskeleton after the initiation of phagocytosis. Several earlier reports have indicated the importance of actin polymerization for NADPH oxidase activity (25Granfeldt D. Dahlgren C. Inflammation. 2001; 25: 165-169Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar, 26Morimatsu T. Kawagoshi A. Yoshida K. Tamura M. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1997; 230: 206-210Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar, 27Tamura M. Kanno M. Endo Y. Biochem. J. 2000; 349: 369-375Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). However, most of these experiments were performed in a cell-free system and did not address the translocation of the cytosolic factors to flavocytochrome b558. Furthermore, inhibition of NADPH oxidase activity in intact cells may well be due to the effects of actin cytoskeleton disruption on primary translocation, which was not identified in these studies. Besides actin-modifying compounds, several other pharmacological agents were tested in PLB-985 p67GFP and GFP-Rac2 cells. In an attempt to identify the mechanism that drives the continuous translocation of p67phox and Rac2, the PLB-985 cells were treated with several inhibitors after the addition of STZ. Among these agents were LY290042 (PI3-kinase inhibitor), staurosporine (a general inhibitor of protein kinase C), SB20358 (an inhibitor of p38MAPK), and U0126 (an inhibitor of pErk). Unfortunately, no effect of any of these inhibitors was found on the continuous translocation of p67GFP and GFP-Rac2. The lack of effect of these inhibitors is probably due to simultaneous stimulation of several signal transduction routes, leading to activation of the NADPH oxidase. Overall, these results indicate that the translocation of p67phox and Rac2 during phagocytosis can be divided into three stages. The first stage is the initiation of phagocytosis after binding of an opsonized particle, in which translocation is dependent on an intact actin cytoskeleton and independent of flavocytochrome b558. The second stage is the formation of the phagosome, during which translocation seems to be independent of flavocytochrome b558 and the cytoskeleton but may be dependent on the interaction of the PX domains of p40phox and p47phox and the prenylated C terminus of Rac2 with the membrane. The last stage, after closure of the phagosome, requires the presence of flavocytochrome b558 for correct localization of p67phox and Rac2. Further studies are needed to elucidate the role of the actin cytoskeleton in NADPH oxidase activity in living cells during phagocytosis as well as the mechanism that drives continuous translocation of p67phox and Rac2 to the phagosomal membrane.

Transcription start site selection in eukaryotes is mediated through combinations of the TATA, initiator (Inr), and downstream promoter elements (DPE). In Trichomonas vaginalis, a parabasalian flagellate thought to represent an ancient eukaryote lineage, the Inr appears to be solely responsible for start site selection and is recognized by the initiator binding protein 39 kDa (IBP39). IBP39 contains an N-terminal Inr binding domain (IBD) connected via a flexible linker to a C-terminal domain (C domain). Here we present crystal structures of the apoIBD and IBD-Inr complexes and the C domain. The IBD structures reveal a winged-helix motif with prokaryotic and eukaryotic features and a scaffold similar to that of ETS-family proteins. The C domain structure and biochemical studies indicate that it interacts with the T. vaginalis RNAP II large subunit C-terminal domain. These data suggest that binding of IBP39 to the Inr directly recruits RNAP II and in this way initiates transcription.

Transcription in the Archaea is carried out by RNA polymerases and transcription factors that are highly homologous to their eukaryotic counterparts, but little is known about the structural organization of the archaeal transcription complex. To address this, transcription initiation complexes have been formed with Pyrococcus furiosus transcription factors (TBP and TFB1), RNA polymerase, and a linear DNA fragment containing a strong promoter. The arrangement of proteins from base pair -35 to +20 (relative to the transcriptional start site) has been analyzed by photochemical protein-DNA cross-linking. TBP cross-links to the TATA box and TFB1 cross-links both upstream and downstream of the TATA box, as expected, but the sites of most prominent TFB1 cross-linking are located well downstream of the TATA box, reaching as far as the start site of transcription, suggesting a role for TFB1 in initiation of transcription that extends beyond polymerase recruitment. These cross-links indicate the transcription factor orientation in the initiation complex. The pattern of cross-linking of four RNA polymerase subunits (B, A′, A″, and H) to the promoter suggests a path for promoter DNA relative to the RNA polymerase surface in this archaeal transcription initiation complex. In addition, an unidentified protein approximately the size of TBP cross-links to the non-transcribed DNA strand near the upstream edge of the transcription bubble. Cross-linking is specific to the polymerase-containing initiation complex and requires the gdh promoter TATA box. The location of this protein suggests that it, like TFB1, could also have a role in transcription initiation following RNA polymerase recruitment. Nucleic Acids Res. 1992; 20: 5423-5428Crossref PubMed Scopus (117) Google Scholar, or the TATA box) about 25 base pairs upstream of the transcription start site (Fig. 1A) (9Rowlands T. Baumann P. Jackson S.P. Science. 1994; 264: 1326-1329Crossref PubMed Scopus (147) Google Scholar). TFB recognizes TBP bound to DNA and makes site-specific interactions with DNA upstream of the TATA box (the B recognition element, BRE; Fig. 1A) (10Qureshi S.A. Jackson S.P. Mol. Cell. 1998; 1: 389-400Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (118) Google Scholar), defining the orientation of the complex, and thus the direction of transcription (11Bell S.D. Cairns S.S. Robson R.L. Jackson S.P. Mol. Cell. 1999; 4: 971-982Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar). This ternary complex recruits RNAP to the promoter for transcription initiation, but the details of interaction between RNAP, TBP, TFB, and promoter DNA in the archaeal transcription initiation complex are not well characterized. The topography of transcription initiation complexes from eukaryotes and bacteria has been studied in detail by DNA site-specific photochemical cross-linking (12Bartholomew B. Durkovich D. Kassavetis G.A. Geiduschek E.P. Mol. Cell Biol. 1993; 13: 942-952Crossref PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar, 13Kim T.K. Lagrange T. Wang Y.H. Griffith J.D. Reinberg D. Ebright R.H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 12268-12273Crossref PubMed Scopus (91) Google Scholar, 14Naryshkin N. Revyakin A. Kim Y. Mekler V. Ebright R.H. Cell. 2000; 101: 601-611Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (159) Google Scholar, 15Korzheva N. Mustaev A. Kozlov M. Malhotra A. Nikiforov V. Goldfarb A. Darst S.A. Science. 2000; 289: 619-625Crossref PubMed Scopus (338) Google Scholar). In conjunction with RNAP structural information, these studies have led to models for eukaryotic and bacterial initiation complexes that delineate the path of promoter DNA relative to the RNAP and transcription factors. We have applied similar cross-linking techniques to analyze the arrangement of proteins in archaeal transcription initiation complexes assembled with promoter DNA and TBP, TFB1 and RNAP from the hyperthermophilic euryarchaeon Pyrococcus furiosus. A preliminary study established the orientation of DNA downstream of the transcriptional start site (modeled using the bacterial RNAP structure) (16Bartlett M.S. Thomm M. Geiduschek E.P. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2000; 7: 782-785Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar). We have extended this analysis and incorporated modifications that have improved the resolution of the data, using proteins from P. furiosus and from two Methanococcaceae. The presented results suggest a path of DNA in a euryarchaeal transcription initiation complex. DNA and Proteins—DNA fragments spanning the P. furiosus gdh promoter (bp -60 to +35 or +37, relative to the transcriptional start as +1) were used for transcription and formation of protein complexes. P. furiosus TFB1, TBP, and RNA polymerase were prepared as described (17Hethke C. Geerling A.C. Hausner W. de Vos W.M. Thomm M. Nucleic Acids Res. 1996; 24: 2369-2376Crossref PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar). Preparation of the corresponding Methanothermococcus thermolithotrophicus and Methanocaldococcus jannaschii proteins has also been described (18Frey G. Thomm M. Brudigam B. Gohl H.P. Hausner W. Nucleic Acids Res. 1990; 18: 1361-1367Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar, 19Hausner W. Thomm M. J. Bacteriol. 2001; 183: 3025-3031Crossref PubMed Scopus (30) Google Scholar, 20Ouhammouch M. Dewhurst R.E. Hausner W. Thomm M. Geiduschek E.P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2003; 100: 5097-5102Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar). All TBPs and TFBs were recombinant proteins, overproduced in Escherichia coli. Transcription Complex Formation—P. furiosus transcription complexes were assembled essentially as described (16Bartlett M.S. Thomm M. Geiduschek E.P. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2000; 7: 782-785Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar): 2 nmgdh promoter DNA was incubated with 20 nm TBP, 60 nm TFB1, and 10 nm RNAP in 12.5 μl of 40 mm sodium HEPES (pH 7.3 at 25 °C), 250 mm NaCl, 2.5 mm MgCl2, 0.1 mm EDTA, 5 mm β-mercaptoethanol, 5% (v/v) glycerol, and 0.1 mg/ml bovine serum albumin (BSA). M. thermolithotrophicus and M. jannaschii transcription complexes were formed with 20 nm TBP, 20 nm TFB, and 6 nm RNAP in 20 mm Tris-Cl (pH 8.0 at 25 °C), 180 mm NaCl, 10 mm MgCl2, 0.1 mm EDTA, 5 mm β-mercaptoethanol, 5% (v/v) glycerol, and 0.1 mg/ml BSA. When indicated, nonspecific DNA competitor (plasmid pUC19 digested with blunt cutters PvuII, RsaI, and BsrBI) was present at 48 μg/ml during complex formation. Complexes were formed at 65 °C (P. furiosus) or 55 °C (M. thermolithotrophicus and M. jannaschii) for 40 min. Heparin was then added (50 μg/ml) along with specific DNA competitor (gdh promoter DNA bp -60 to +37 at 400 nm) when indicated. In transcription reactions NTPs were added (to 500 μm ATP, GTP, and CTP, and 10 μm [α-32P]UTP at 40 Ci/mmol) 30 s after heparin addition, reactions were incubated at 65 °C (P. furiosus) or 55 °C (M. thermolithotrophicus and M. jannaschii) for 20 min, and transcription was halted by addition of an equal volume of deionized formamide containing bromphenol blue and xylene cyanol (each at 1 mg/ml). Cross-linking—For cross-linking, protein-DNA complexes were formed as above, using internally α-32P-labeled gdh promoter derivatives containing azidophenacylated phosphorothioate or AB-dUMP (5-[N′-(p-azidobenzoyl)-3-aminoallyl]dUMP) at specific locations, prepared as described (16Bartlett M.S. Thomm M. Geiduschek E.P. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2000; 7: 782-785Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar). Probes were radiolabeled by DNA polymerase-directed incorporation of radioactive dNTP(s) (3000 Ci/mmol) 3′ to the phosphorothioate-containing dNTP or AB-dUMP; therefore individual probes contained one to four radioactive nucleotides, as follows: four radiolabels in probe -11NT and -7T; three in -31NT, -15NT, -27T, -11T; two in -35NT, -23NT, -9NT, +8NT, +14NT, +16NT, +20NT, -33T, -15T, -9T, +4T, +6T, +14T, +16T, and +19T; the rest of the probes had one radioactive nucleotide. Reaction mixtures were UV irradiated at 65 °C (P. furiosus) or 55 °C (M. thermolithotrophicus and M. jannaschii), as described (21Bartholomew B. Tinker R.L. Kassavetis G.A. Geiduschek E.P. Methods Enzymol. 1995; 262: 476-494Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar) 30 s after addition of heparin (no DNA competitors), or 10 min after addition of heparin and specific DNA competitor, as specified. Following cross-linking, complexes were treated with nuclease and analyzed on 4-20% gradient polyacrylamide-SDS gels, essentially as described (21Bartholomew B. Tinker R.L. Kassavetis G.A. Geiduschek E.P. Methods Enzymol. 1995; 262: 476-494Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). Cross-linked proteins were detected by autoradiography using phosphor image plates. Where indicated, UV-irradiated complexes were separated on 4% polyacrylamide native gels, bands containing the desired protein-DNA complexes were excised from the gel, and complexes were eluted overnight in 800 μl elution buffer (10 mm Tris, 0.05% SDS, and 15 μg/ml BSA), then concentrated by microfiltration and washed 3× with 500 μl of transcription reaction buffer (lacking glycerol and BSA). Washed eluates were concentrated to about 15 μl, and processed using DNase I and micrococcal nuclease (10 units of each); entire samples were loaded onto 4-20% gradient polyacrylamide-SDS gel for analysis. Chemical Cleavage of RNAP Subunit H—Typical cross-linking reactions were performed using P. furiosus polypeptides and gdh promoter DNA containing AB-dUMP at bp +19 of the transcribed (T) strand. Reaction products were processed with nuclease, and proteins were separated on 4-20% gradient polyacrylamide-SDS gels. Radiolabeled bands were visualized by phosphor imaging, and the cross-linked small RNAP subunit was excised and eluted overnight in 450 μl of 10 mm Tris pH 8.0, 0.2% SDS, and 25 μg/ml BSA. Eluates were concentrated by microfiltration, and the concentrated eluate was divided and treated with various chemical cleavage reagents. Cyanogen bromide (CNBr) and 2-nitro-5-thiocyanobenzoic acid (NTCB) treatments were performed as described (22Shah S.M. Kumar A. Geiduschek E.P. Kassavetis G.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 28736-28744Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar) except that CNBr treatment was for 16 h at 300 mm, and NTCB treatment was for 3.5 h at 50 mm to induce more complete cleavage at methionine and cysteine residues, respectively. Mock treatments were identical but lacked CNBr or NTCB. For cleavage at Asp-Pro (23Jue R.A. Doolittle R.F. Biochemistry. 1985; 24: 162-170Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar), formic acid was added to 50% (v/v) and reacted at 40 °C for 16 h. CNBr was then added to 0.9 mm; after 3 min at room temperature, reaction samples were diluted 10-fold with water, dried down by vacuum centrifugation, resuspended in protein gel sample buffer and analyzed by 6-25% gradient polyacrylamide-SDS gel electrophoresis; labeled proteins were visualized by phosphor image plate autoradiography. A DNA site-specific photochemical cross-linking method was used to examine the path of DNA through the archaeal transcription initiation complex. A set of photoactive DNA probes was constructed by attaching a single azidophenacyl (AP) group to every other nucleotide on both strands of the P. furiosus (Pfu) glutamate dehydrogenase (gdh) promoter, covering bp -35 to +20 (relative to the transcriptional start site as +1; Fig. 1A). Probes were checked for ability to support specifically initiating run-off transcription at 65 °C and this led to two interesting observations: 1) Derivatization with azidophenacyl bromide (APB) in a segment of the non-transcribed (NT) strand comprising its open transcription bubble (24Spitalny P. Thomm M. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 30497-30505Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar) and ∼2 flanking base pairs increased transcription activity; the non-polar AP group at these locations may favor polymerase recruitment or, more probably, promoter opening. 2) AP derivatization at the downstream end of the transcribed (template) strand blocked transcript elongation (data not shown). Promoter complexes were formed with these DNA probes, recombinant Pfu transcription factors TBP and TFB1, and native Pfu RNA polymerase (RNAP) at 65 °C and irradiated at the same temperature. A similar approach had been used previously to map cross-links to Pfu RNAP subunits B, A′, and A″ to downstream segments (bp -5 to +20) of the gdh promoter transcribed strand. Homology considerations and the structure of a bacterial RNA polymerase core enzyme (25Zhang G. Campbell E.A. Minakhin L. Richter C. Severinov K. Darst S.A. Cell. 1999; 98: 811-824Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (672) Google Scholar) were used to derive a model of the DNA trajectory and specify the orientation of DNA in the archaeal transcription complex (16Bartlett M.S. Thomm M. Geiduschek E.P. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2000; 7: 782-785Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar). Extension of this analysis to both strands of the promoter, and covering bp -35 to +20, showed cross-links to RNAP subunits between the TATA box and the start site, cross-links to TBP near the TATA box, and cross-links to TFB1 both upstream and downstream of the TATA box. There were also unexpected RNAP cross-links within and upstream of the TATA box, and cross-links to TFB1 that appeared likely to be due to nonspecific binding (data not shown). A DNA competition step was therefore introduced to address the possible presence of nonspecifically bound complexes, based on reasoning that nonspecific binding of transcription factors and RNAP would be diminished by an excess of nonspecific DNA, and that those nonspecific complexes that did form would be less avidly bound and therefore selectively unstable to a subsequent challenge by an excess of specific competitor. Transcription initiation complexes were assembled essentially as described previously (16Bartlett M.S. Thomm M. Geiduschek E.P. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2000; 7: 782-785Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar) and under “Experimental Procedures,” but in the presence of a 400-fold excess of nonspecific competitor DNA (linearized, fragmented bacterial plasmid) during 40 min allowed for complex formation, and then challenged with a 200-fold molar excess of specific competitor (wild-type gdh promoter DNA) for 10 min, before cross-linking. The presence of nonspecific competitor was found to have only a minimal effect on the formation of active transcription complexes (tested by a transcription assay; data not shown) but reduced formation of nonspecific complexes. A representative data set for cross-linking of initiation complexes using the competition protocol is shown for both strands of the gdh promoter in Fig. 1 B and C. RNA Polymerase Cross-links—Most cross-linking to Pfu RNAP was to subunits B, A′, and A″, the archaeal homologues of eukaryotic RNA polymerase II subunits Rpb2 (B) and Rpb1 (A′ and A″). Pfu subunit B was cross-linked between bp -9 and +2 of the non-transcribed (NT) strand and between bp -15 and ∼+14 of the transcribed (T; template) strand. Weak cross-linking to subunit B within and upstream of the TATA box most probably represents residual incorrectly assembled complexes, since the amount of cross-linking to B in this promoter segment (relative to other sites) was reduced in the presence of competitors (data not shown). Subunit A′ was cross-linked mainly to the T strand between bp -7 and +6, with a pair of cross-links to the NT strand at bp +8 and +10. Subunit A″ cross-linked to both the T and NT strands between ∼bp -1 and +20. The A′ and A″ cross-links observed for the transcribed strand are consistent with previously reported results (16Bartlett M.S. Thomm M. Geiduschek E.P. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2000; 7: 782-785Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar). Cross-links to a small polypeptide (∼7-10 kDa) were observed between bp +12 and +20 on the T strand, and bp +14 to +20 on the NT strand, and chemical cleavage was used to identify this small protein as RNAP subunit H (Fig. 2). Cross-links were formed using a photoactive probe with AB-dUMP at bp +19 of the T-strand, which yields the most efficient cross-linking. The cross-linked protein was excised from the gel, eluted, and then treated with cyanogen bromide (cleaving at methionine), NTCB (cleaving at cysteine), or formic acid (cleaving between aspartic acid and proline). The results in Fig. 2B indicate that the small protein lacks Met and Cys, but contains at least one Asp-Pro motif. The experiment was repeated with probes containing AP-derivatized phosphorothioate in the T strand at bp +12 and +16, with the same result (data not shown). The only Pfu small RNAP subunit with this profile is subunit H (Pf1655, 9.2 kDa); the other small RNAP subunits (E″, Pf0255, 6.9 kDa; F, Pf1036, 14.1 kDa; K, Pf1642, 6.2 kDa; L, Pf0050, 11.1 kDa; M, Pf0986, 12.9 kDa; N, Pf1643, 8.9 kDa and P, Pf2009, 5.7kDa; see www.tigr.org/tigr-scripts/CMR2/LocusNameSearch.spl?db = ntpf01 for sequences) (26Robb F.T. Maeder D.L. Brown J.R. DiRuggiero J. Stump M.D. Yeh R.K. Weiss R.B. Dunn D.M. Methods Enzymol. 2001; 330: 134-157Crossref PubMed Scopus (191) Google Scholar) are necessarily excluded as candidates. Subunit H is the archaeal homologue of eukaryotic Rpb5, which is located in close proximity to DNA downstream of the transcription start site in eukaryotic initiation complexes (13Kim T.K. Lagrange T. Wang Y.H. Griffith J.D. Reinberg D. Ebright R.H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 12268-12273Crossref PubMed Scopus (91) Google Scholar, 27Kim T.K. Ebright R.H. Reinberg D. Science. 2000; 288: 1418-1422Crossref PubMed Scopus (215) Google Scholar). Transcription Factor Cross-links—The 2.4 Å structure of Pfu TBP and the C-terminal two-thirds of TFB1 bound to TATA-box DNA (5Littlefield O. Korkhin Y. Sigler P.B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 13668-13673Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar) specifies that TBP should be cross-linked by probes spanning the TATA box (bp -30 to -22) and that TFB1 should cross-link to DNA just upstream and just downstream of the TATA box. The results shown in Fig. 1 confirm these predictions. In addition, extensive cross-linking of TFB1 was observed downstream of the TATA box, extending nearly to the transcriptional start site on the NT strand, and to bp of +6 of the T strand. These results suggest a trajectory for the N-terminal one-third of TFB1. There were also unexpected cross-links to a 20-25 kDa protein (the same size as TBP) at bp -13 to -7 of the NT strand. The just-described patterns of cross-linking were obtained with mixtures of TFB1, TBP, RNAP, and DNA and might be contributed by transcription factor-DNA complexes or polymerase-containing transcription initiation complexes. In order to focus attention on initiation complexes, these were separated by non-denaturing polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis from DNA complexes containing only TBP and TFB1 (see Fig. 1 of Ref. 16Bartlett M.S. Thomm M. Geiduschek E.P. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2000; 7: 782-785Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar). Fig. 3 shows the results of such an experiment in which each lane corresponds to an irradiated sample that has been subjected to gel electrophoresis, the part of the gel containing initiation complexes excised, proteins, and DNA eluted and concentrated, and the sample subsequently processed by nuclease digestion, SDS-PAGE and autoradiography as for Fig. 1. Cross-links of RNAP subunits to the non-transcribed (Fig. 3A) and transcribed (Fig. 3B) strands were essentially unchanged relative to Fig. 1, as expected. Cross-links to the transcription factors, which could now be specifically assigned to initiation complexes, were generally similar to those observed in the absence of fractionation, but with some significant differences: the relative intensity of cross-links to TFB1 on the T strand was somewhat reduced downstream of bp -3; the intensity of T strand cross-links to TFB1 between bp -23 and -7 was more uniform than before; the NT strand cross-links to TBP at bp -23 was relatively prominent. Variations of efficiency of cross-linking may in part reflect the manipulative complexity of this experiment and, potentially, differential effects of derivatization with APB on formation of TBP-TFB1 and TBP-TFB1-RNAP complexes. However, the principal and clear-cut outcome of the experiment is the observation that TFB1 in RNA polymerase-containing initiation complexes is accessible to cross-linking from both strands of a promoter segment that extends nearly to the transcriptional start site. The relationship of cross-linking efficiency in TFB1-TBP-DNA complexes and polymerase-containing initiation complexes was explored further by excising transcription factor bands from separation gels and subjecting them to the same analysis. The result of such an experiment with T strand probes for bp -5 to +6 is presented in Fig. 3C. Comparison with Fig. 3B shows that the strongest cross-links to TFB1 in the factors-only complex are with probes -1T and +2T with significant cross-linking to bp +6, whereas the strongest cross-links in the initiation complex are with probe -5T and cross-linking fades out downstream of bp -1. This result indicates that at least some downstream cross-links to TFB1 occur even in the absence of RNAP. It was surprising to find a protein co-migrating with TBP prominently cross-linked to the NT strand far downstream of the TATA box in polymerase-containing transcription complexes (Fig. 3A), near the upstream end of the transcription bubble (24Spitalny P. Thomm M. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 30497-30505Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar). To investigate this further, transcription initiation complexes were formed with probes -9NT and -7NT, and irradiated; TFB1-TBP-DNA complexes were separated from transcription initiation complexes and analyzed (Fig. 3D). The striking result of this experiment is that relatively efficient cross-linking of the TBP-sized protein to bp -9 of the T strand is specific to polymerase-containing complexes, as is the much weaker cross-linking to bp -7 of the same strand. In contrast, TFB1 is located within cross-linking range of both these sites in the transcription factor and transcription initiation complexes. Most of the cross-links observed in Figs. 1, 2, 3 are consistent with current models for transcription complexes, as discussed below, but some suggest novel/unanticipated (functional) interactions. In particular, it was important to verify that cross-links to the TBP-sized protein at bp -13 to -7 of the NT strand are contributed by specifically assembled complexes, since they are not compatible with the structure of the Pfu TBP-TFB1-TATA DNA complex (regarded as static). The numerous and strong cross-links to TFB1 between the TATA box and the transcription start site could also indicate mechanistically important interactions in initiation of transcription and had to be verified. To examine specificity further, we used a derivative of the gdh promoter with two TATA box mutations (Fig. 4A) that inactivate the promoter (16Bartlett M.S. Thomm M. Geiduschek E.P. Nat. Struct. Biol. 2000; 7: 782-785Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar), presumably by preventing TBP binding and transcription complex assembly. DNA cross-linking with wild-type and TATA mutant promoters AP-derivatized at several positions between bp -35 and +19 was examined (Fig. 4B). Cross-links to RNAP subunits and transcription factors generally required an intact TATA box, specifying that these cross-links arise from specific and correctly assembled transcription complexes. Only two exceptions were apparent: 1) the cross-link to RNAP subunit B at bp -35 was found to be independent of the TATA box, and not correlated with TFB1 or TBP cross-linking, suggesting that this signal is due to misassembled RNAP, possibly residual factor-independent polymerase binding to the upstream end of the probe; 2) weak cross-links to TFB1 and RNAP subunit B (relative to A″) at bp +12 of the T strand were also seen to be at least partly independent of the TATA box. It should be noted that this experiment was done without nonspecific or specific competitors present; the nonspecific cross-links at bp +12 of the T strand may disappear under more stringent conditions. In the course of our experiments we observed that the Pfu gdh promoter is recognized by purified transcription factors and RNAP from M. thermolithotrophicus (Mth) and M. jannaschii (Mja) (Fig. 5A). 2C. Hethke and M. Thomm, unpublished results. Transcription with the Mth and Mja factors and RNAPs was less efficient than with Pfu RNAP and factors under the conditions used, but transcription start sites were seen to be identical (Fig. 5A). We examined cross-linking of Mth and Mja transcription factors and RNAP using cross-linking probes derivatized at numerous positions in the gdh promoter, in several experiments that were carried out in the absence of competitors. Data for selected probes are shown in Fig. 5B. Subunit B is split in the Methanococcaceae, B″ corresponding approximately to the N-terminal half of Pfu subunit B, and B′ approximately to the C-terminal half. Mth and Mja RNAP subunit A′ was cross-linked by probe +4T, while A″ was cross-linked by probes +4T as well as +16NT. (Mja subunit A″ and TFB are of similar size and mobility, making these two proteins difficult to distinguish on the gel). Subunit B″ was cross-linked by all the probes shown with variable efficiency, while B′ was cross-linked at bp -7 and +4 of the T strand. TBP cross-linked at the TATA box (probe -29T), and TFB cross-linked upstream as well as downstream of the TATA box. Numerous experiments (

The nervous system must observe a complex world and produce appropriate, sometimes complex, behavioral responses. In contrast to this complexity, neural responses are often characterized through very simple descriptions such as receptive fields or tuning curves. Do these characterizations adequately reflect the true dimensionality reduction that takes place in the nervous system, or are they merely convenient oversimplifications? Here we address this question for the target-selective descending neurons (TSDNs) of the dragonfly. Using extracellular multielectrode recordings of a population of TSDNs, we quantify the completeness of the receptive field description of these cells and conclude that the information in independent instantaneous position and velocity receptive fields accounts for 70%-90% of the total information in single spikes. Thus, we demonstrate that this simple receptive field model is close to a complete description of the features in the stimulus that evoke TSDN response.

To examine the role of the estrogen response element (ERE) sequence in binding of liganded estrogen receptor (ER) to promoters, we analyzed in vivo interaction of liganded ER with the imperfect ERE in the pS2 gene and the composite estrogen-responsive unit (ERU) in the proteinase inhibitor 9 (PI-9) gene. In transient transfections of ER-positive HepG2-ER7 cells, PI-9 was strongly induced by estrogen, moxestrol (MOX), and 4-hydroxytamoxifen (OHT). PI-9 was not induced by raloxifene or ICI 182,780. Quantitative reverse transcriptase-PCR showed that moxestrol strongly induced cellular PI-9 and pS2 mRNAs, whereas OHT moderately induced PI-9 mRNA and weakly induced pS2 mRNA. Chromatin immunoprecipitation experiments demonstrated strong and similar association of 17β-estradiol-hERα and MOX-hERα with the PI-9 ERU and with the pS2 ERE. Binding of MOX-hERα to the PI-9 ERU and the pS2 ERE was rapid and continuous. Although MOX-hERα bound strongly to the PI-9 ERU and less well to the pS2 ERE in chromatin immunoprecipitation, gel shift assays showed that estrogen-hERα binds with higher affinity to the deproteinized pS2 ERE than to the PI-9 ERU. Across a broad range of OHT concentrations, OHT-hERα associated strongly with the pS2 ERE and weakly with the PI-9 ERU. ICI-hERα bound poorly to the PI-9 ERU and effectively to the pS2 ERE. Raloxifene-hERα and MOX-hERα exhibited similar binding to the PI-9 ERU and the pS2 ERE. These studies demonstrate that ER ligand and ERE sequence work together to regulate in vivo binding of ER to estrogen-responsive promoters.

The reaction mechanism of the esterase 2 (EST2) from Alicyclobacillus acidocaldarius was studied at the kinetic and structural level to shed light on the mechanism of activity and substrate specificity increase previously observed in its double mutant M211S/R215L. In particular, the values of kinetic constants (k1, k(-1), k2, and k3) along with activation energies (E1, E(-1), E2, and E3) were measured for wild type and mutant enzyme. The previously suggested substrate-induced switch in the reaction mechanism from kcat=k3 with a short acyl chain substrate (p-nitrophenyl hexanoate) to kcat=k2 with a long acyl chain substrate (p-nitrophenyl dodecanoate) was validated. The inhibition afforded by an irreversible inhibitor (1-hexadecanesulfonyl chloride), structurally related to p-nitrophenyl dodecanoate, was studied by kinetic analysis. Moreover the three-dimensional structure of the double mutant bound to this inhibitor was determined, providing essential information on the enzyme mechanism. In fact, structural analysis explained the observed substrate-induced switch because of an inversion in the binding mode of the long acyl chain derivatives with respect to the acyl- and alcohol-binding sites.

Tumor necrosis factor-related apoptosis-inducing ligand receptor 3 (TRAIL-R3) is a decoy receptor for TRAIL, a member of the tumor necrosis factor family. In several cell types decoy receptors inhibit TRAIL-induced apoptosis by binding TRAIL and thus preventing its binding to proapoptotic TRAIL receptors. We studied the regulation of TRAIL-R3 gene expression in breast tumor cells treated with the genotoxic drug doxorubicin (DXR). The breast tumor cell line MCF-7 (p53 wild type) responded to DXR with a marked elevation of TRAIL-R3 expression at the mRNA, total protein, and cell surface levels. In contrast, in EVSA-T cells (p53 mutant) DXR did not induce increased expression of TRAIL-R3. In MCF-7 cells overexpressing the human papillomavirus protein E6, which causes p53 degradation, DXR-induced TRAIL-R3 expression was notably reduced. Furthermore, in MCF-7 cells overexpressing a temperature-sensitive p53 mutant (Val135), shifting the cultures to the permissive temperature was sufficient to induce the expression of TRAIL-R3. We also cloned and characterized a p53 consensus element located within the first intron of the human TRAIL-R3 gene. This element binds p53 and confers responsiveness to genotoxic damage to constructs of the TRAIL-R3 promoter in transient transfection experiments. Our results indicate that genotoxic treatments such as DXR, frequently used in cancer therapy, may also induce genes such as TRAIL-R3 that potentially have antiapoptotic actions and thus interfere with the TRAIL signaling system. This is particularly important in view of the proposed use of TRAIL in antitumor therapy. Our results indicate that genotoxic treatments such as DXR, frequently used in cancer therapy, may also induce genes such as TRAIL-R3 that potentially have antiapoptotic actions and thus interfere with the TRAIL signaling system. This is particularly important in view of the proposed use of TRAIL in antitumor therapy. TRAIL-R3 lacks the cytoplasmic and transmembrane domains and is bound to the cell surface through a glycosylphosphatidylinositol lipid anchor. Ectopic overexpression of TRAIL-R3 in TRAIL-sensitive cells confers resistance to TRAIL-induced apoptosis (5Sheridan J.P. Marsters S.A. Pitti R.M. Gurney A. Skubatch M. Baldwin D. Ramakrishnan L. Gray C.L. Baker K. Wood W.I. Goddard A.D. Godowski P. Ashkenazi A. Science. 1997; 277: 818-821Crossref PubMed Scopus (1528) Google Scholar). Furthermore removal of TRAIL-R3 from the cell surface by phosphatidylinositol-specific phospholipase C has been shown to turn TRAIL-resistant cells into sensitive cells (5Sheridan J.P. Marsters S.A. Pitti R.M. Gurney A. Skubatch M. Baldwin D. Ramakrishnan L. Gray C.L. Baker K. Wood W.I. Goddard A.D. Godowski P. Ashkenazi A. However, studies in other systems showed no correlation between TRAIL-R3 expression and sensitivity to TRAIL-induced apoptosis (13LeBlanc H.N. Ashkenazi A. Cell Death Differ. 2003; 10: 66-75Crossref PubMed Scopus (755) Google Scholar). A definitive demonstration of the antiapoptotic action of TRAIL-R3 in apoptosis induced by TRAIL thus requires further studies. The TRAIL-R3 gene maps to human chromosome 8p22-21, clustered with the genes encoding TRAIL-R1, -R2 (8Degli-Esposti M.A. Smolak P.J. Walczak H. Waugh J. Huang C.P. DuBose R.F. Goodwin R.G. Smith C.A. J. Exp. Med. 1997; 186: 1165-1170Crossref PubMed Scopus (558) Google Scholar), and -R4 (9Degli-Esposti M.A. Dougall W.C. Smolak P.J. Waugh J.Y. Smith C.A. Goodwin R.G. Immunity. 1997; 7: 813-820Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (744) Google Scholar). It consists of five exons interrupted by four introns and spans ∼14.5 kb. The first exon encodes the 5′ untranslated region and the first 60 amino acid residues of the open reading frame. Exon II codes for the next 35 amino acids, from position 61 to 95, and includes the predicted signal peptide cleavage site (8Degli-Esposti M.A. Smolak P.J. Walczak H. Waugh J. Huang C.P. DuBose R.F. Goodwin R.G. Smith C.A. J. Exp. Med. 1997; 186: 1165-1170Crossref PubMed Scopus (558) Google Scholar). Exons III and IV encode the two cysteine-rich domains characteristic of the TNF receptor family. The rest of the protein is encoded by exon V. This region contains the extreme carboxyl-terminal hydrophobic region, the 88-amino acid linker sequence, and the 3′ untranslated region. Tissue and cellular distribution of TRAIL-R3 transcripts seems to be more restricted compared with the other TRAIL receptors (8Degli-Esposti M.A. Smolak P.J. Walczak H. Waugh J. Huang C.P. DuBose R.F. Goodwin R.G. Smith C.A. J. Exp. Med. 1997; 186: 1165-1170Crossref PubMed Scopus (558) Google Scholar). Its transcripts have been detected in some normal tissues, and they can also be observed in most transformed cell lines but in substantially lower amounts. However, very little is known about the regulation of TRAIL-R3 expression. Overexpression of c-Rel or activation of endogenous Rel/NF-κB factors by TNF-α have been reported to up-regulate TRAIL-R3 expression and confer resistance to TRAIL-induced apoptosis (11Bernard D. Quatannens B. Vandenbunder B. Abbadie C. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 27322-27328Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar). TRAIL-R3 is also induced by genotoxic agents in a p53-dependent manner and is overexpressed in primary tumors of the gastrointestinal tract (14Sheikh M.S. Huang Y. Fernandez-Salas E.A. El-Deiry W.S. Friess H. Amundson S. Yin J. Meltzer S.J. Holbrook N.J. Fornace Jr., A.J. Oncogene. 1999; 18: 4153-4159Crossref PubMed Scopus (132) Google Scholar). These findings give urgency to understanding the mechanisms controlling the transcriptional regulation of TRAIL-R3 expression in tumor cells because treatments that elevate its levels may dampen the potential effectiveness of TRAIL-based therapies. By using nested PCR we recently cloned the promoter region of the TRAIL-R3 gene (15Ruiz de Almodóvar C. López-Rivas A. Redondo J.M. Rodríguez A. FEBS Lett. 2002; 531: 304-308Crossref PubMed Scopus (7) Google Scholar), which contains a consensus TATA box sequence as well as potential binding sites for several transcription factors. However, despite being a p53-regulated gene, no p53 consensus binding site is located within the described promoter region (15Ruiz de Almodóvar C. López-Rivas A. Redondo J.M. Rodríguez A. FEBS Lett. 2002; 531: 304-308Crossref PubMed Scopus (7) Google Scholar). The proapoptotic receptors CD95 and TRAIL-R2 are also up-regulated by p53 after genotoxic damage in various cell types (16Sheikh M.S. Burns T.F. Huang Y. Wu G.S. Amundson S. Brooks K.S. Fornace Jr., A.J. El-Deiry W.S. Cancer Res. 1998; 58: 1593-1598PubMed Google Scholar, 17Ruiz-Ruiz M.C. López-Rivas A. Cell Death Differ. 1999; 6: 271-280Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar, 18Muller M. Wilder S. Bannasch D. Israeli D. Lehlbach K. Li-Weber M. Friedman S.L. Galle P.R. Stremmel W. Oren M. Krammer P.H. J. Exp. Med. 1998; 188: 2033-2045Crossref PubMed Scopus (733) Google Scholar). In the CD95 and TRAIL-R2 genes, the p53 consensus element responsible for the observed up-regulation is located within the first intron of the gene (18Muller M. Wilder S. Bannasch D. Israeli D. Lehlbach K. Li-Weber M. Friedman S.L. Galle P.R. Stremmel W. Oren M. Krammer P.H. J. Exp. Med. 1998; 188: 2033-2045Crossref PubMed Scopus (733) Google Scholar, 19Takimoto R. El-Deiry W.S. Oncogene. 2000; 19: 1735-1743Crossref PubMed Scopus (310) Google Scholar). In this report, we describe the expression levels of TRAIL receptors in breast cancer cells before and after genotoxic treatment with doxorubicin (DXR), a commonly used drug in breast cancer therapy. Our results revealed a p53-dependent elevation of TRAIL-R1, -R2, and -R3 receptors in these cells. We also identified a p53 consensus element within the first intron of the TRAIL-R3 gene, which is involved in the observed up-regulation of expression upon genotoxic treatment. Reagents and Antibodies—RPMI 1640 medium and fetal bovine serum were obtained from Invitrogen. DXR was from Sigma Immunochemicals. Anti-human TRAIL receptor antibodies for Western blots were purchased from R&D Systems (Minneapolis, MN). Anti-human TRAIL receptor antibodies for flow cytometry studies were from Alexis Corp. (San Diego, CA). Anti-human p53 and p21 antibodies were purchased from Calbiochem and Santa Cruz Biotechnology (Santa Cruz, CA), respectively. All restriction enzymes were from Roche Applied Science. T4 DNA ligase was purchased from New England Biolabs (Beverly, MA). Cell Lines—The human tumor cell lines MCF-7 and EVSA-T were maintained in RPMI 1640 medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, 2 mml-glutamine, and 40 μg/ml gentamycin at 37 °C in a humidified 5%CO2, 95% air incubator. MCF-7 cells stably expressing the human papillomavirus type 16 E6 protein or the temperature-sensitive p53 mutant p53Val135were previously generated in our laboratory and maintained in culture as described previously (17Ruiz-Ruiz M.C. López-Rivas A. Cell Death Differ. 1999; 6: 271-280Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar). Reverse Transcriptase and PCR Assays—Total RNA was isolated from MCF-7 cells with the TRIzol RNA isolation system (Invitrogen) as recommended by the supplier. cDNAs were synthesized from 2 μg of total RNA using a reverse transcriptase PCR kit (PerkinElmer Life Sciences) with the supplied oligo(dT) primer under conditions described by the manufacturer. PCRs were performed using the following primers: hTRAIL sense, 5′-CAACTCCGTCAGCTCGTTAGAAAG-3′, and hTRAIL antisense, 5′-TTAGACCAACAACTATTTCTAGCACT-3′; hTRAIL-R1 sense, 5′-CTGAGCAACGCAGACTCGCTGTCCAC-3′, and hTRAIL-R1 antisense, 5′-TCCAAGGACACGGCAGAGCCTGTGCCAT-3′; hTRAIL-R2 sense, 5′-GCCTCATGGACAATGAGATAAAGTGGCT-3′, and hTRAIL-R2 antisense, 5′-CCAAATCTCAAAGTACGCACAAACGG-3′; hTRAIL-R3 sense, 5′-GAAGAATTTGGTGCCAATGCCACTG-3′, and hTRAIL-R3 antisense, 5′-CTCTTGGACTTGGCTGGGAGATGTG-3′; hTRAIL-R4 sense, 5′-CTTTTCCGGCGGCGTTCATGTCCTTC-3′, and hTRAIL-R4 antisense, 5′-GTTTCTTCCAGGCTGCTTCCCTTTGTAG-3′; human β-actin sense, 5′-TGACGGGGTCACCCACACTGTGCCCTTC-3′, and human β-actin antisense, 5′-CTAGAAGCATTTGCGGTGGACGATGGAGGG-3′, whose products were 443, 506, 502, 612, 453, and 661 bp long, respectively. Cycle conditions for all the PCRs were 1 min at 95 °C, 1 min at 55 °C, and 1 min at 72 °C. The number of cycles varied depending on the TRAIL receptor analyzed. The products were resolved on a 1% agarose gel and visualized with ethidium bromide. Flow Cytometry—To detect TRAIL receptors at the cell surface, control cells or cells treated with DXR (500 ng/ml, 15 h) were detached with RPMI 1640 medium, 3 mm EDTA, washed with PBS, and suspended in 200 μl of PBS. Cells were incubated with primary antibodies (5 μg/ml) at 4 °C for 30 min. After washing with PBS to remove unbound primary antibody, cells were incubated with rabbit anti-mouse fluorescein isothiocyanate-conjugated antibody (Dako) (dilution 1:20) for 30 min at 4 °C. Cells were then washed again with PBS, suspended in 200 μl of PBS, and analyzed in a FACScan flow cytometer using the Cell Quest software (BD Biosciences). Immunoblot Detection of Proteins—After detachment with trypsin, 0.25% EDTA or PBS, 3 mm EDTA, cells (3 × 105) were washed with PBS, and protein content was measured before lysing the cells in Laemmli sample buffer under reducing conditions. Cell lysates were sonicated, and proteins were resolved on SDS-polyacrylamide gels and detected as described previously (17Ruiz-Ruiz M.C. López-Rivas A. Cell Death Differ. 1999; 6: 271-280Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar). Plasmid Constructs—Wild-type and mutant versions of the TRAIL-R3 intronic p53-binding site were generated by annealing the corresponding synthetic complementary oligonucleotides. The double-stranded oligonucleotides had overhang ends to direct their cloning between BamHI (5′ end) and HindIII (3′ end) restriction sites (italic residues in oligonucleotide sequences indicate the restriction enzyme sites). The sequences of the oligonucleotides used were: 5′-GATCCCGGCCGGGCATGTCCGGGCAGGACGAACTCA-3′ and 5′-AGCTTGAGTTCGTCCTGCCCGGACATGCCCGGCCGG-3′ for wtp53-BS and 5′-GATCCCGGCCGGGAAAATCCGGGAAAAACGAACTCA-3′ and 5′-AGCTTGAGTTCGTTTTTCCCGGATTTTCCCGGCCGG-3′ for mutp53-BS. For the annealing reaction each pair of complementary primers was mixed at a final concentration of 25 μm, each in an annealing buffer containing 10 mm Tris-Cl (pH 7.5), 50 mm NaCl, 10 mm MgCl2, and 1 mm dithiothreitol. The annealing mixture was incubated at 90 °C for 4 min, and the reaction mixture was allowed to cool down to room temperature. pIBS-506Luc and pmIBS-506Luc constructs, which respectively contain the wtp53-BS and mutp53-BS upstream of a 506-bp portion of the TRAIL promoter, were generated from the TRAIL-R3 promoter reporter plasmid (p-1641luc) described previously (15Ruiz de Almodóvar C. López-Rivas A. Redondo J.M. Rodríguez A. FEBS Lett. 2002; 531: 304-308Crossref PubMed Scopus (7) Google Scholar). p-1641luc was digested with BamHI and HindIII to release a 1135-bp fragment of the TRAIL-R3 promoter, which was replaced by either the wt or mutant p53-binding site. The p506Luc construct was obtained by filling BamHI and HindIII ends with Klenow and religating the blunted ends. To generate the pTR3Luc reporter plasmid, which includes the intronic p53-binding site in its native genomic context, PCR with Klen-Taq-LA polymerase mixture (Clontech) was used to amplify a 976-bp fragment of the TRAIL-R3 gene containing 533 bp of the promoter, all of exon I, and the first 181 bp of the first intron, which span the p53-binding site. The following combination of primers were used for this: sense, 5′-GGGGGATCCGAGGGATACCAAGCCC-3′, and antisense, 5′-GGGAAGCTTGTCCCTCCTGCCCAGCC-3′. The PCR product was cloned directly into the pGEM-T vector (Promega). A 949-bp fragment was released from this construct by HindIII digestion and finally cloned into a HindIII-digested pXP2 plasmid. A QuikChange site-directed mutagenesis kit (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA) was used to obtain the pmTR3Luc construct following the manufacturer's instructions. The mutation (underlined nucleotides) was generated with the following oligonucleotides: sense, 5′-CTGCGGCCGGGGGGGTCCGGGCAGG-3′; and antisense, 5′-CCTGCCGGACCCCCCCGGCCGCAG-3′. This construct was sequenced to confirm the expected mutation. pC53-SN3 and pC53-SCX3 plasmids, encoding wt p53 and an Ala143 mutant p53, respectively, were generously provided by Dr. M. Oren (Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel). Transient Transfection and Reporter Activity Assay—Transient transfection experiments were conducted in MCF-7 cells with the FuGENE 6 transfection reagent (Roche Applied Science) as indicated by the manufacturer. Briefly 2 × 105 cells/well were seeded into 6-well plates the day before transfection. 0.75 μg of luciferase reporter plasmid and 0.25 μg of β-galactosidase plasmid were mixed with the FuGENE 6 reagent and added to each well. Twelve hours after transfection cells were treated with DXR (500 ng/ml) for 15 h. For co-transfection with wild-type or mutant p53 plasmids, 0.5 μg of luciferase reporter plasmid, 0.25 μg of p53 expression plasmid, and 0.25 μg of β-galactosidase plasmid were mixed with the FuGENE 6 reagent, and cells were incubated with the transfection mixture for 36 h. After incubation, cells were harvested, and luciferase activity was measured according to the instructions of the luciferase system kit (Promega). Transfection efficiency was normalized by measuring the β-galactosidase activity. Transfection experiments were performed in triplicate. Electrophorectic Mobility Shift Assays (EMSAs)—For nuclear protein extractions, MCF-7 cells were treated with DXR (500 ng/ml) for 6 h. Cells were lysed in 400 μl of hypotonic buffer (10 mm HEPES, pH 7.6, 10 mm KCl, 0.1 mm EDTA, 0.1 mm EGTA, 1 mm dithiothreitol, 0.5 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 10 mm Na2MoO4, protease inhibitors, 0.75 mm spermidine, and 0.15 mm spermine) containing 0.6% Nonidet P-40. Nuclei were then centrifuged and washed once with a detergent-free hypotonic buffer and incubated in 50 μl of high salt-containing buffer (20 mm HEPES, pH 7.6, 400 mm KCl, 1 mm EDTA, 1 mm EGTA, 1 mm dithiothreitol, 0.5 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 10 mm Na2MoO4, and protease inhibitors) for 30 min on a rocking platform at 4 °C. Nuclei were centrifuged at 13,000 rpm in a microcentrifuge for 10 min, and supernatants containing the nuclear extracts were immediately stored at –80 °C. The protein concentration was quantified by the Bradford procedure. Electrophoretic mobility shift assays were performed as described previously(20Lorenzo E. Ruiz-Ruiz C. Quesada A.J. Hernandez G. Rodríguez A. López-Rivas A. Redondo J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 10883-10892Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar). Nuclear proteins (4 μg) were incubated with 2.0 μg of poly(dI-dC) DNA carrier and 4 μl of 5× DNA binding buffer (10% polyvinyl ethanol, 12.5% (v/v) glycerol, 50 mm Tris (pH 8), 2.5 mm EDTA, and 2.5 mm dithiothreitol) in a final volume of 20 μl for 10 min on ice. Next 2 μl (5 × 104 cpm/μl) of 32P-labeled double-stranded oligonucleotide was added to the reaction mixture, which was then incubated at room temperature for 30 min. For competition assays, a 100 m excess of unlabeled double-stranded oligonucleotide was added to the cellular extract prior to the addition of the 32P-labeled probe. When indicated, 100 ng of the anti-p53 antibody (pAb421, Calbiochem) or a control antibody (identical isotype) was added to the cellular extract prior to the 32P-labeled probe. The sequences (5′ to 3′) of the oligonucleotides used in these studies (corresponding to the p53 sequence located within the first intron of the human TRAIL-R3 gene) were as follows: gatccCGGCCGGGCATGTCCGGGCAGGACGAACTCa (sense) and agcttGAGTTCGTCCTGCCCGGACATGCCCGGCCGg (antisense). Up-regulation of TRAIL Receptors in Breast Tumor Cells Treated with DXR—To increase the sensitivity of cancer cells to TRAIL, different DNA-damaging treatments have been used (21Chinnaiyan A.M. Prasad U. Shankar S. Hamstra D.A. Shanaiah M. Chenevert T.L. Ross B.D. Rehemtulla A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 1754-1759Crossref PubMed Scopus (487) Google Scholar, 22Keane M.M. Ettenberg S.A. Nau M.M. Russell E.K. Lipkowitz S. Cancer Res. 1999; 59: 734-741PubMed Google Scholar). The synergism observed between TRAIL and DNA-damaging agents in the induction of apoptosis is likely to be the result of p53-dependent up-regulation of proapoptotic TRAIL receptors (21Chinnaiyan A.M. Prasad U. Shankar S. Hamstra D.A. Shanaiah M. Chenevert T.L. Ross B.D. Rehemtulla A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 1754-1759Crossref PubMed Scopus (487) Google Scholar, 23Wu G.S. Burns T.F. McDonald III, E.R. Meng R.D. Kao G. Muschel R. Yen T. El-Deiry W.S. Oncogene. 1999; 18: 6411-6418Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar, 24Guan B. Yue P. Clayman G.L. Sun S.Y. J. Cell Physiol. 2001; 188: 98-105Crossref PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar). However, TRAIL decoy receptors are also up-regulated after genotoxic damage (14Sheikh M.S. Huang Y. Fernandez-Salas E.A. El-Deiry W.S. Friess H. Amundson S. Yin J. Meltzer S.J. Holbrook N.J. Fornace Jr., A.J. Oncogene. 1999; 18: 4153-4159Crossref PubMed Scopus (132) Google Scholar) and may prevent TRAIL-induced apoptosis. We have analyzed the expression of the TRAIL decoy receptor TRAIL-R3 (also known as DcR1) in the breast tumor cell line MCF-7 and its regulation by genotoxic stress. Treatment of MCF-7 cells with DXR resulted in the up-regulation of proapoptotic TRAIL-R1 and TRAIL-R2 mRNA expression (Fig. 1A). In these cells, expression of decoy receptor TRAIL-R3 mRNA was also markedly increased by DXR treatment (Fig. 1A). Similar results were obtained using the anti-metabolite drug methotrexate as the genotoxic agent (not shown). By contrast, TRAIL and decoy receptor TRAIL-R4 mRNAs, which are expressed in MCF-7 cells prior to treatment with DXR, were not up-regulated after this treatment (Fig. 1A). These results were consistent with the altered protein levels at the cell surface of treated cells detected by flow cytometry. Fig. 1B shows that DXR treatment slightly increased the expression of TRAIL-R1. TRAIL-R2 was expressed in untreated cells, and its expression was further elevated by DXR (Fig. 1B), confirming the results reported by other authors in various cell types (16Sheikh M.S. Burns T.F. Huang Y. Wu G.S. Amundson S. Brooks K.S. Fornace Jr., A.J. El-Deiry W.S. Cancer Res. 1998; 58: 1593-1598PubMed Google Scholar). Of the decoy receptors, TRAIL-R4 was expressed at the cell surface of MCF-7 cells prior to treatment, and its expression levels did not change after incubation with DXR. By contrast, TRAIL-R3 protein could not be detected by flow cytometry at the cell surface of untreated MCF-7 cells, but its expression was markedly increased upon treatment (Fig. 1B). Elevated TRAIL-R3 Expression Induced by DXR in Breast Tumor Cells Is Dependent on p53—It has been reported that the tumor suppressor protein p53, which participates in the cellular response to DNA damage, is involved in the up-regulation of the expression of several apoptosis-related genes, including death receptors (25Vousden K.H. Lu X. Nat. Rev. Cancer. 2002; 2: 594-604Crossref PubMed Scopus (2728) Google Scholar). To address the role of p53 in DXR-induced TRAIL receptor up-regulation in breast tumor cells, we compared the expression levels of TRAIL receptors in breast tumor MCF-7 (wild-type p53) and EVSA-T (inactive mutant p53) cells before and after treatment with DXR. We also analyzed the effect of DXR in these cell lines on the accumulation of p53 and the expression of WAF1/p21, a protein whose gene is regulated by p53 (26Levine A.J. Cell. 1997; 88: 323-331Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (6740) Google Scholar). Fig. 2A shows that in MCF-7 cells, the p53 level was low in untreated cultures and was markedly elevated after drug treatment. By contrast, untreated EVSA-T cells showed a high level of p53 expression, and there was only a small increase after treatment. Consistent with this, the expression of WAF1/p21 was up-regulated by DXR treatment in only MCF-7 cells, confirming that p53 expressed in EVSA-T cells is transcriptionally inactive. The results shown in Fig. 2A demonstrate that contrary to the findings in MCF-7 cells, DXR failed to elevate the expression of TRAIL-R1, -R2, or -R3 in EVSA-T cells. These results suggest that p53 may be required for the up-regulation of TRAIL receptors in response to genotoxic stress. To confirm this we used MCF-7 cells that express the human papillomavirus type 16 E6 protein (17Ruiz-Ruiz M.C. López-Rivas A. Cell Death Differ. 1999; 6: 271-280Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar). Overexpression of E6 protein causes the degradation of p53 via the proteasome pathway and thus prevents the transcriptional activation of p53 target genes (27Kessis T.D. Slebos R.J. Nelson W.G. Kastan M.B. Plunkett B.S. Han S.M. Lorincz A.T. Hedrick L. Cho K.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 3988-3992Crossref PubMed Scopus (506) Google Scholar). We have previously reported that overexpression of E6 protein in MCF-7 cells prevents the up-regulation of CD95/Fas receptor that takes place in response to genotoxic stress (28Ruiz-Ruiz C. Robledo G. Cano E. Redondo J.M. López-Rivas A. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 31667-31675Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar) As shown in Fig. 2B, MCF-7E6 cells failed to accumulate p53 in response to DXR treatment and showed a complete absence of TRAIL-R3 upregulation. Likewise up-regulation of TRAIL-R1 and -R2 by DXR was abrogated, and we also observed a markedly lower induction of WAF1/p21 in MCF-7E6 cells when compared with MCF-7neo (control) cells. The data presented so far indicated that p53 accumulation is a necessary event for the up-regulation of TRAIL-R1, -R2, and -R3 expression in breast tumor cells treated with DXR. This prompted us to examine whether accumulation of active p53 was sufficient to elevate TRAIL receptor expression in MCF-7 cells. For this we used MCF-7 cells stably expressing a temperature-sensitive mutant of mouse p53 (Val135) (17Ruiz-Ruiz M.C. López-Rivas A. Cell Death Differ. 1999; 6: 271-280Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar). Shifting the cells from the restrictive temperature (37–38 °C), at which the protein adopts an inactive conformation, to a lower temperature (32 °C) triggers the adoption of an active wild-type conformation (29Michalovitz D. Halevy O. Oren M. Cell. 1990; 62: 671-680Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (690) Google Scholar) capable of inducing the expression of the p53-regulated gene WAF1/p21 (Fig. 2C). Fig. 2C shows that control (puro) cells did not express TRAIL-R3 protein at either temperature. By contrast, TRAIL-R3 protein expression, which was low in MCF-7p53ts cells maintained at 37 °C, was notably elevated after incubation at the permissive temperature for 48 h. Similar results were obtained when the proapoptotic receptors TRAIL-R1 and -R2 were analyzed (Fig. 2C). A p53 Consensus Sequence Located within the First Intron of the TRAIL-R3 Gene Mediates DXR-induced Activation of TRAIL-R3 Gene Promoter Activi

The initial step in the biosynthesis of the clinically important β-lactamase inhibitor clavulanic acid involves condensation of two primary metabolites, d-glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate and l-arginine, to give N2-(2-carboxyethyl)arginine, a β-amino acid. This unusual N-C bond forming reaction is catalyzed by the thiamin diphosphate (ThP2)-dependent enzyme N2-(2-carboxyethyl)arginine synthase. Here we report the crystal structure of N2-(2-carboxyethyl)arginine synthase, complexed with ThP2 and Mg2+, to 2.35-Å resolution. The structure was solved in two space groups, P212121 and P21212. In both, the enzyme is observed in a tetrameric form, composed of a dimer of two more tightly associated dimers, consistent with both mass spectrometric and gel filtration chromatography studies. Both ThP2 and Mg2+ cofactors are present at the active site, with ThP2 in a “V” conformation as in related enzymes. A sulfate anion is observed in the active site of the enzyme in a location proposed as a binding site for the phosphate group of the d-glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate substrate. The mechanistic implications of the active site arrangement are discussed, including the potential role of the aminopyrimidine ring of the ThP2. The structure will form a basis for future mechanistic and structural studies, as well as engineering aimed at production of alternative β-amino acids. The initial step in the biosynthesis of the clinically important β-lactamase inhibitor clavulanic acid involves condensation of two primary metabolites, d-glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate and l-arginine, to give N2-(2-carboxyethyl)arginine, a β-amino acid. This unusual N-C bond forming reaction is catalyzed by the thiamin diphosphate (ThP2)-dependent enzyme N2-(2-carboxyethyl)arginine synthase. Here we report the crystal structure of N2-(2-carboxyethyl)arginine synthase, complexed with ThP2 and Mg2+, to 2.35-Å resolution. The structure was solved in two space groups, P212121 and P21212. In both, the enzyme is observed in a tetrameric form, composed of a dimer of two more tightly associated dimers, consistent with both mass spectrometric and gel filtration chromatography studies. Both ThP2 and Mg2+ cofactors are present at the active site, with ThP2 in a “V” conformation as in related enzymes. A sulfate anion is observed in the active site of the enzyme in a location proposed as a binding site for the phosphate group of the d-glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate substrate. The mechanistic implications of the active site arrangement are discussed, including the potential role of the aminopyrimidine ring of the ThP2. The structure will form a basis for future mechanistic and structural studies, as well as engineering aimed at production of alternative β-amino acids. An important mechanism of bacterial resistance to β-lactam antibiotics involves β-lactamase-catalyzed hydrolysis of the β-lactam ring, resulting in biologically inactive products (1Matagne A. Dubus A. Galleni M. Frère J.-M. Nat. Prod. Rep. 1999; 16: 1-18Crossref PubMed Scopus (182) Google Scholar). Clavulanic acid (Fig. 1), one of many β-lactams produced by Streptomyces clavuligerus, is the most widely used inhibitor of the serine β-lactamases, and is clinically administered in combination with the penicillin amoxycillin (2Jensen S.E. Paradkar A.S. Antonie Leeuwenhoek Int. J. Gen. Mol. Microbiol. 1999; 75: 125-133Crossref PubMed Scopus (67) Google Scholar, 3Baggaley K.H. Brown A.G. Schofield C.J. Nat. Prod. Rep. 1997; 14: 309-333Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar). Clavulanic acid is itself a bicyclic β-lactam, and reacts with the β-lactamases to form stable acyl-enzyme complexes (4Brown R.P. Aplin R.T. Schofield C.J. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 12421-12432Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar, 5Knowles J.R. Acc. Chem. Res. 1985; 18: 97-104Crossref Scopus (222) Google Scholar). A commercially viable synthesis of clavulanic acid is rendered difficult by the high lability and density of functionalization around the bicyclic core (3Baggaley K.H. Brown A.G. Schofield C.J. Nat. Prod. Rep. 1997; 14: 309-333Crossref PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar, 6Bentley P.H. Brooks G. Gilpin M.L. Hunt E. Tetrahedron Lett. 1979; 20: 1889-1890Crossref Scopus (10) Google Scholar). Consequently clavulanic acid is produced by fermentation and there is considerable interest in its biosynthetic pathway. A total of 18 genes from the genome of S. clavuligerus have thus far been implicated in clavulanic acid biosynthesis (7Mellado E. Lorenzana L.M. Rodriguez-Saiz M. Diez B. Liras P. Barredo J.L. Microbiol. SGM. 2002; 148: 1427-1438Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar, 8Li R.F. Khaleeli N. Townsend C.A. J. Biol. 2000; 7: 127-133Crossref PubMed Scopus (252) Google Scholar). open reading frame N2-(2-carboxyethyl)arginine synthase thiamin diphosphate yeast pyruvate decarboxylase electrospray ionization mass spectrometry Zymomonas mobilis pyruvate decarboxylase. N2-(2-Carboxyethyl)arginine synthase (CEAS) is the enzyme product of the first gene in the clavulanic acid cluster, orf2. It catalyzes the first step in the clavulanic acid pathway, the condensation of l-arginine and a three-carbon precursor to give N2-(2-carboxyethyl)arginine (Fig. 1). On the basis of turnover experiments with a variety of potential three carbon precursors the best substrate identified was d-glyceraldehyde 3-P (12Khaleeli N. Li R. Townsend C.A. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1999; 121: 9223-9224Crossref Scopus (82) Google Scholar). Sequence analysis indicated the presence of a conserved thiamin diphosphate (ThP2) binding fold, and indeed, CEAS catalysis has been shown to be dependent on ThP2 (12Khaleeli N. Li R. Townsend C.A. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1999; 121: 9223-9224Crossref Scopus (82) Google Scholar). ThP2-dependent enzymes generally employ the cofactor both to effect nucleophilic attack at a carbonyl group and to stabilize the carbanion subsequently formed by proton transfer or decarboxylation. The reactions catalyzed by ThP2 enzymes may be subclassified as either non-oxidative, such as those of yeast pyruvate decarboxylase (PDC) (23Jordan F. Nat. Prod. Rep. 2003; 20: 184-201Crossref PubMed Scopus (201) Google Scholar) and benzoylformate decarboxylase (24Hasson M.S. Muscate A. McLeish M.J. Polovnikova L.S. Gerlt J.A. Kenyon G.L. Petsko G.A. Ringe D. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 9918-9930Crossref PubMed Scopus (164) Google Scholar), or oxidative, such as those of pyruvate oxidase (25Muller Y.A. Schulz G.E. Science. 1993; 259: 965-967Crossref PubMed Scopus (215) Google Scholar, 26Bertagnolli B.L. Hager L.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 10168-10173Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). More recently, several ThP2 enzymes that catalyze atypical reactions have been identified, including CEAS and 2-hydroxyphytanoylcoenzyme A lyase, an enzyme involved in the degradation of phytanic acid that is derived from the side chain of chlorophyll (27Foulon V. Antonenkov V.D. Croes K. Waelkens E. Mannaerts G.P. Van Veldhoven P.P. Casteels M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1999; 96: 10039-10044Crossref PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar). In addition to its key role in clavam biosynthesis, CEAS is of mechanistic interest due to the unprecedented manner in which a ThP2-dependent enzyme is used in a N-C bond forming reaction, proposed to proceed via an α,β-unsaturated acyl-ThP2 intermediate. Here we report the crystal structure of CEAS complexed with ThP2 and Mg2+, and discuss the mechanistic implications arising. Protein Expression and Purification—The ceas gene was PCR amplified and subcloned directly as an NdeI/BamHI fragment into the pET24a(+) vector (Novagen). Primers used were: forward, 5′-acgctcatatgtcccgtgta-3′; reverse, 5′-ggacatgagcggtctcccgactccgtcagtacc-3′. Following amplification, the integrity of ceas was confirmed by DNA sequencing. The ceas/pET24a(+) construct was transformed into Escherichia coli BL21(DE3) and grown at 37 °C in 2TY medium containing 30 μg/ml kanamycin. Protein production was induced at an A600 of 0.8 by addition of isopropyl-β-d-thiogalactopyranoside to a final concentration of 1.0 mm, following reduction of the temperature to 30 °C. CEAS was purified by sequential use of Q-Sepharose and phenyl-Resource chromatography. Size exclusion chromatography (Superdex S200) was used as a final step to yield CEAS of >95% purity by SDS-PAGE analysis. Electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) revealed that the mass of the isolated CEAS was consistent with loss of N-terminal methionine from the predicted amino acid sequence (observed, 60,776 Da; calculated without N-terminal methionine, 60,776 Da). N-terminal amino acid sequence analysis (observed, SRVSTAPSGK) confirmed the identity of the protein and the loss of the N-terminal methionine. The activity of purified CEAS was confirmed by high performance liquid chromatography assay and comparison with known synthetic standards. Selenomethionine-substituted Protein Expression—Selenomethionine-substituted CEAS was produced using a metabolic inhibition protocol and LeMaster media supplemented with 50 mg/liter l-selenomethionine. Selenomethionine incorporation was >95% by ESI-MS. Native Molecular Weight Determination—The “native” molecular weight of CEAS was determined by size exclusion chromatography (Superdex 200 HR). Calibration was carried out using cytochrome c (12 kDa), chymotrypsin (25 kDa), ovalbumin (43 kDa), bovine serum albumin (67 kDa), aldolase (158 kDa), and blue dextran (2000 kDa) (Gel Filtration Calibration kit, Amersham Biosciences). An elution volume parameter (Kav) was calculated for each of the calibration proteins and a calibration curve was constructed. By calculating Kav for CEAS the native molecular weight was established. Crystallization—Crystallization conditions were initially sought by the vapor diffusion method, using commercially available crystallization screens. Hanging drops of 2 μl of protein (10 mg/ml), containing a 3-fold excess of thiamin diphosphate, and 2 μl of well solution were suspended at 17 °C over a well solution containing 1.6 m ammonium sulfate and 0.1 m HEPES, pH 7.4. Under these conditions, crystals of two different morphologies grew over a period of 2 weeks. The crystals belonged to two different space groups, however, the shape of the crystals was not a determinant of the space group. The majority of the crystals belonged to space group P212121, with unit cell dimensions a = 117.7 Å, b = 127.3 Å, c = 196.8 Å. The remainder of the crystals belonged to space group P21212, with unit cell dimensions a = 123.1 Å, b = 187.2 Å, c = 198.6 Å. Crystallographic Data Collection and Structure Solution—Crystals were cryocooled by plunging into liquid nitrogen and x-ray data were collected at 100 K using a nitrogen stream. Cryoprotection was accomplished by sequential transfer into solutions of 1.8 m ammonium sulfate, containing 10% (v/v) glycerol and 25% glycerol. Data from selenomethionine-substituted crystals was collected on beamline BM14 at the European Synchrotron Radiation Facility, Grenoble, France, using a MarCCD detector. All other data were collected on beamlines 14.1 and 14.2 of the Synchrotron Radiation Source, Daresbury, UK. The data were processed using MOSFLM (28Leslie A.G. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D Biol. Crystallogr. 1999; 55: 1696-1702Crossref PubMed Scopus (485) Google Scholar) and the CCP4 suite of programs (29Collaborative Computational Project Number 4 Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D Biol. Crystallogr. 1994; 50: 760-763Crossref PubMed Scopus (19797) Google Scholar). The selenomethionine-substituted crystal used for the structure solution belonged to the P212121 space group. Using SHELXD (30Schneider T.R. Sheldrick G.M. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D Biol. Crystallogr. 2002; 54: 1772-1779Crossref Scopus (1580) Google Scholar), 40 selenium positions were determined, corresponding to four molecules per asymmetric unit, excluding the N-terminal methionine that was not present by N-terminal sequencing and ESI-MS. Phasing and density modification were performed using CNS (31Brunger A.T. Adams P.D. Clore G.M. DeLano W.L. Gros P. Grosse-Kunstleve R.W. Jiang J.S. Kuszewski J. Nilges M. Pannu N.S. Read R.J. Rice L.M. Simonson T. Warren G.L. Acta Crystallogr. Sect. D Biol. Crystallogr. 1998; 54: 905-921Crossref PubMed Scopus (16979) Google Scholar). The phases had a figure of merit of 0.38 over the resolution range to 2.35 Å, which rose to 0.94 following density modification.
